Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Jeez... knock off the chatter, will ya.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Just trying to keep you awake, Arch.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: I'm awake! Where do you come up with all that crap about women?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: It's true. Women are very complex, but if you know how to read 'em... they're an open book. You can always tell the rotten apples from the peaches.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Are you kiddin'?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'd stake my career on it. Anybody ever proves me wrong, I'll throw away my badge.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Aayyhh... women are trouble...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I used to believe that too. Until I married Lana. Now, she... is a peach.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Yeah, well you're a lucky stiff, pal. Ya hold down two jobs. Got a beautiful wife waitin' for ya at home. Everything a guy could ever want, including NO kids.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'd love to have kids.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: What?! Rug-rats? Give me a break!  Jeez, I hate stakeouts. What makes you think Milo's gonna show up here?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Logic. He knocked off all those banks. He's got cash. He's gonna want to spend it. This is one of the few places that still takes cash. Sooner or later... he's gotta turn up.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: And how we s'posed to recognize this scumbag?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: The "Support Hose Bandit"? When you see him... you'll know him.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: These are the best damn Nachos in North America. Maybe the world!

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: I'm empty. I'm gonna get a refill. You want some?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Got a light?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: How about a match?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No thanks. I have plenty.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: You really are incredibly stupid, aren't you? I like that in a man.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'd be insulted, but I know you're serious.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: You sound so sure of yourself.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'm not as dumb as I look.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Let me buy you a drink, Mr. uh...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Ravine. Ned Ravine. And you are...?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Thirsty. What about that drink?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'm on duty.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Brain surgeon?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Cop.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Oooo... and I bet you have a big gun.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You lose.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: If I can't buy you a drink...  ...let me buy you one of those.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Who can say no to a weiner?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Not me.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Two dogs. Hot.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You come here often?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Only when I'm in heat.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh! Sorry.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Where ya going?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Get something to wipe it off.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: That's okay. You're doing just fine.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'll get you a wet paper towel.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Hold it right there, Milo!

Speaker: restroom patron
Dialogue: Look out! He's got a weenie!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Police emergency! I need your car!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You take science in high school, Milo?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: I skipped high school, cop!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Then you're probably not familiar with the theory of inverse proportionate explosive dynamics.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: If you fire a weapon with the barrel obstructed, the explosive force multiplies by twenty-three point five nine eight and reverses on itself with diametric polarity?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Yeah. So?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: The gun will blow up in your hand... and it won't even scorch my pinkie.

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Ha! That's just theoretical hypothesis. Inverse proportionate explosive dynamics has never been demonstrated conclusively in a laboratory environment.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh yeah. Then pull the trigger, smart guy. Let's find out.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You have the right to remain silent... next... if you waive that right, anything you say... next...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...may be used against you in a court of law... next... You have the right to an attorney... Do you have an attorney?

Speaker: milo
Dialogue: Nahhhh!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Then today's your lucky day...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Not bad for an auto mechanic...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yeah, well you're not so bad yourself... for a lawyer's wife...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Better watch your tongue, sweetie, or I'll have my husband arrest you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Busy man. Cop and a lawyer. When does he ever find time for you?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: He doesn't. That's why I need you to keep my engine tuned, Frank. Why drive a jalopy when you can have a hot rod?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Maybe you should trade him in on a new model.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I would... if I could make any money on the deal.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Want to go for another test drive?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Pull over and park it, Frank. I'm still under warranty.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Morning sweetheart.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Uh huh. Want some coffee?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No thanks.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Frank here was just grabbing a little before going back to work on my car.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: How long you been working on Lana's Mercedes, Frank?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh... I don't know... six, seven weeks.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And ya still haven't found the problem?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Think I got my finger on it though.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I know what he's doing, Lana. I wasn't born yesterday. He's not fixing your car. He's SCREWING you!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: YOU are screwing my wife! I can see what your game is, Frank. You open up her hood, poke around in there... squirt some lubrication in... play around with all her parts... then take an old used piston and stick it in... then pull it out... in, out, in, out! Every day! There's no end to it. You just keep coming and COMING!... and the bill just gets bigger and BIGGER!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But you don't see it, do you, Lana? You're too good... too pure. You can't see the evil in people like him.  Well, you're not getting away with it, pal. I'm pulling the plug! You're fired!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Ned... don't you have to be somewhere?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh... yeah. Thanks, honey. I'm late for court.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You are so naive.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Finish your coffee... then GET OUT!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Who's that?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Just the postman. He always rings twice.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Laura... do you know where...?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Right here. The judge decided to skip arraignment and take Milo direct to trial. You're six minutes late, but don't sweat it. You got Judge Allen. He's always eleven minutes late.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I suggest you try Lemming versus Florida, 1956... where the guy jumped in the water and everybody followed.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. Good idea.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I don't know what I'd do without you?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Laura, how long have you worked for me?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Two years, seven months, twenty-three days, nineteen hours...  ...fifty-three... fifty-four... fifty- five... fifty-six...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And when was the last time I gave you a raise?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Never. But that's okay. I don't need a raise. In fact... I was thinking of giving you a rebate on my salary.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Naw. That's okay. You keep it.

Speaker: laura's husband
Dialogue: Did we forget something?

Speaker: laura's husband
Dialogue: Did we forget something?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Laura. Laura! What is it?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I'm okay, I'm okay. I just get a bit... claustrophobic... in the bathroom.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Maybe we should try some prune juice.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Wear the blue one.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen... I ask you... does this look like the face of a crook?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Of course it does. But the question of my client's guilt or innocence is not the issue here today. I'm certain every member of the jury can clearly see that he's guilty!

Speaker: blind juror
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Put yourself in his shoes. Look through his eyes. See the world the way HE sees it!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Things just don't look the same. It's fuzzy... and frightening!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen... Milo Crumley is not the perpetrator here. He is the VICTIM!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Like ALL of us... this man is the unfortunate victim of these tragically difficult economic times. And what does that mean? He can't support his family!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: For God's sake!... He can't even support his own FACE!

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: Mr. Crumley... you cannot chew gum in my courtroom... unless you have enough for everyone.

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: Bailiff. Pass these out.

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: And don't forget the jury.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And so, desperate and broke, with no other options before him, Mr. Crumley went to eleven Savings & Loans and did what any of you would have done. He stole back the money that the S&Ls had stolen from him!

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: Mr. Ravine... please approach the bench.

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: You're not running for congress here, so knock off the speeches and quit inciting these brainless morons! Now pick up the pace and wrap this son- of-a-bitch up! Call your first witness.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I call... Detective Ned Ravine.

Speaker: bailiff
Dialogue: Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Detective Ravine, at the time of the arrest, did you read the defendant his Miranda rights?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Of course. That's standard procedure.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Are these the cards Officer Brooks used to prompt you while reading Mr. Crumley his rights?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. These are them.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Reading from the cards now... quote "You have the right to remain silent, if you waive that right, anything you say... may be used against you in a court of law." Is that right?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Don't you know the difference between "can" and "may", Detective? Every school kid knows "can" is a verb that indicates ability to perform, while "may" is a verbal auxiliary indicating the permission to act.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I didn't have time to worry about past participles or interrogative pronouns! I was trying to protect society from a deranged MADMAN!  But this ivy league fop...!!!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I have no more use for this witness.

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: Mr. Ravine...

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: I'm dismissing this case on the grounds of improper grammar.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Ow!

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: But your Honor...!

Speaker: judge allen
Dialogue: I know, I know. It's a technicality. But it's the kind of technicality that makes the American legal system what it is today! Court's adjourned!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I waited. You never came back.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I got busy. Here's that paper towel I promised.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Thanks...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: How'd you get in? The door was locked.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: It's miraculous what a real woman can do... with a bobbie pin.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Cigarette?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No... thanks. They're bad for ya.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes, I know. I like things that are bad for me.  So... I hear you go both ways.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Only once. It was a fraternity prank. I never saw him again.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: No, I mean... you're a cop and a lawyer.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh. Yeah. Well, there's a lot of scum out there on the streets... but they all deserve a fair and costly trial.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I'll get that.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh... Laura... this is, uh...

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Lola Cain.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: So lovely to meet you, Laura.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Gotta keep these darn books in their right place or we'll never find the ones we need. Let's see, Q thru M... R thru B... W thru F...

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: It's getting late. I'll give you a ride home, Ned.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I have my car.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I'll tow you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Not today. You don't need to wait. I'll see you tomorrow.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I should call someone to fix this...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Tomorrow...

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I'll call from home.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I think I should warn you, Mr. Ravine... I'm not wearing any underwear.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Try these on.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: So... what can I do for you?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I've run across some... papers... and I thought you might be able to tell me what they are. You see, I'm not very experienced when it comes to... papers.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'll help you Miss Cain, if I'm able. Do you have the... papers... here?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: No... they're at home. I thought you might stop by...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'm on duty tonight.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Don't they ever give you a night off?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. Tomorrow.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Why don't we meet tomorrow evening then?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I'll let you know where.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What's wrong with my office?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Nothing a good interior decorator couldn't fix.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Take care of this for me, will ya?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I came back for my shower cap.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Yeah, well you came to the right place.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Where is he?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: On duty all night. By the time he wraps up his reports, it'll be close to noon tomorrow.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I was just reading over...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Take off the hat, Frank.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I was just reading over my husband's insurance policies. You wouldn't know anything about insurance, would you, Frankie?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yeah, matter of fact, I sell policies part-time. I got half a brain... or didn't you notice?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I musta had my eye on something else.  How about a translation.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Standard accident policy... all the usual stuff... blah, blah, blah. The face value is... Wow. Not bad. Three million bucks!  And there's a triple indemnity rider.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Meaning?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Aw, it's just something agents throw in so we can boost the premium. If the policy holder dies under very specific conditions, it pays off three times the face value of the policy.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Nine million dollars...?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yeah... but it's a sure bet for the company. Nobody ever collects.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, like here... it only pays off if he's shot with a pistol, falls from a moving northbound train and drowns in a fresh water stream.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: All three?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: See what I mean, sweetheart? What are the odds of that?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: It could happen.  Suppose it did happen?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Then you'd be rich.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Then we'd be rich.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What're you sayin'...?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: We're gonna kill the son-of-a-bitch! And I know exactly how! He has a legal symposium in Santa Barbara this weekend... All we have to do is get him to take the train up instead of driving.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How we gonna do that? Didn't you tell me he hates trains?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: That's where you come in, baby. You're gonna rig his car so it doesn't work. That should be no problem for you.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Then... we give him a lift to the train station... through Dealey Plaza, past the Book Suppository and around the grassy knoll...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Isn't that out of our way?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Move, Frank.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: And pay attention.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Ten minutes out of the station he'll be standing in the vestibule between cars... trying to avoid a panic attack. Fourteen minutes and ten seconds out, the train crosses the Santa Ynez River. So at thirteen minutes and fifty-four seconds, I shoot him, shove him out the door... he hits the river and drowns. Bingo! A triple play. We're rich!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You been thinking about this a lot, haven't you?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: No. It just came to me.  I had this image of a big, powerful, throbbing train... plunging into a long, dark, wet tunnel.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Stand over there and shut up!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Watch your mouth, punk! I don't want to hear language like that!

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Whoa, hold on, hoss! Take it easy. You seem a little tense tonight. What is it?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Aw... I don't know. I guess it's Lana. It's just... I know she wants to have a baby so bad...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...but I never get to spend any time with her. And when I am home... it's like she's, you know... avoiding sex.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That can't be it. I'm the tenderest guy on the force. Nah... I think she's just afraid she won't be able to get pregnant.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: What's to be afraid! It's like making breakfast! You bring home the bacon... she's got the eggs. Ya scramble it up. Ba-da-boom ba-da-bing! She's got an omelette in the oven!  Why don't you knock off early... go home. It'd be nice for Lana to wake up in the morning and find you there for a change.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Naw... I can't. I got all this paperwork.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Don't worry about that.

Speaker: willard scott
Dialogue: ...and Mrs. Prudy Ann Camomile of Delphi, Georgia is one-hundred and thirteen! What a gorgeous hunk of female! Smokes three cigars a day, drinks a straight shot of vodka at bedtime... and still has sex!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Damn birds!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: My God, Ned... you look like you were hit by a bus.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I was.  Who's in my office?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Max Shady's mother.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Not again.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Hello, Mrs. Shady.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Laura... check on my insurance. Make sure it's paid up.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Gee, has it been seven years already?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Well, being locked in a tiny room with no TV can make a guy feel pretty tense.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'm sure the experience wasn't all negative. He probably made a lot of friends...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...learned a useful trade...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...caught up on all those books he wanted to read...

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh my God, Ned.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I hate when she comes to see me.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Don't you realize, Ned?... you could be in real danger.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Extreme peril. You know, the risk of personal bodily harm.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No... I mean that.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Your insurance file. But the policy's missing. Did you take it home?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh, wait a second...

Speaker: laura's husband
Dialogue: Lau-raaaaa!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Laura! Are you alright? That was a very long flashback you had.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Yes... I know. It's okay. I'm just a little... pre-menstrual.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: That Lola Cain... "person"... stopped by. She left this!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh yeah, before I forget... you asked me to take care of this.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Thanks...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You smoke too much.  It's hot tonight.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Is it? I never know. My body heat runs about twenty degrees above normal.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Maybe we should look for a cooler place.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I doubt we'll find one. Even the wind chimes on my porch aren't moving much these days. They keep thudding softly, like dairy cows bumping butts in the night. I go out there expecting to find a cool breeze... but it's just a lot of hot air.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What're they lookin' at?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: A lot of them have tried that seat. You're the first one's lasted this long.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I feel honored.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Don't. It's broken.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Did you bring the... papers?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: No. I thought you might come over...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Sure. I'll drive you.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I brought my own car.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'll follow you then.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I know it sounds silly, but would you leave first... wait in your car? I come here a lot and I wouldn't want those men to think I'm "easy"... a slut who'll jump into bed with anyone at the drop of a hat. But if you leave first...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...they'll think I'm a putz for passing up a sure thing.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Now leave me alone!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Well, here we are... in the dark.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I have The Clapper.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You what?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: My wind chimes.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You know, these would work a lot better if you took them out of the boxes.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Well well... I guess you have been around. I'm impressed.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Why don't we take a look at those... papers?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Papers. Right.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That's it? These are the... papers?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes. They're so confusing to me. Can you tell me what they are?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: This one's a laundry receipt... and the other one's an expired lottery ticket.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: No. You keep them... as a memento of our time together.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I'm so grateful. How can I ever repay you for all you've done?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Cash would be nice.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Isn't there some other way?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I suppose you could wash my car.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: No, I mean, isn't there something else you want? Something I could give you?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Hey... slow down... there's a speed limit in this state. Sixty-five miles an hour.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: How fast was I going, officer?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh, about a hundred and twenty-three.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Suppose you pull me over and frisk me?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Suppose I let you off with a warning?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Suppose I find a cop with a bigger nightstick?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Suppose I put you under arrest for being a bad girl with bad thoughts?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Suppose you handcuff me to the bed?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Nah... I better be going.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: You're not so tough. Last chance.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No thanks. I got a cold shower and a wife who trusts me waiting at home.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: What's the matter? Don't you want me? It's the way I look, isn't it?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Don't forget to lock up.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I knew you'd come back...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I forgot my car keys.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: That's not what you came back for.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yes it is.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: ...don't... stop...

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: ...Oh Ned... please... don't... stop...

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: That takes care of foreplay.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: It's time, Max.

Speaker: max shady
Dialogue: Find Ned Ravine... rip his head off and use it for a bowling ball!

Speaker: max shady
Dialogue: Yeah. The bastard gave it to me as a gift... to make up for losing my case. Now I'm going to wear it to his friggin' funeral!!

Speaker: max shady
Dialogue: Ma!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That's Madam Butterfly, isn't it?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Iron Butterfly. In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh yeah, sure... now I can hear it.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: It tells the sad story of a woman who is rejected by her lover after a brief, but torrid, affair... so she stalks him with an ice pick and stabs him with it more than a thousand times.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Really? I never could understand the lyrics.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You know, what happened last night was very, uh...

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes... it was. I should check on my homeowners insurance.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But we can't ever let it happen again. Ever!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: What are you saying, Ned? That you're rejecting me, your lover, after a brief, but torrid, affair?!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I wouldn't put it exactly like that. It's just that... well, I'm married to a wonderful woman... who is very, very attractive...  ...not that you aren't very attractive!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...you aren't very attractive... you aren't very attractive... you aren't very attractive...

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Don't touch anything. You bond with it... you buy it. Whatdya want?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'd like to buy a pet.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yeah. For what purpose?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: It's a gift... for my wife.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Right. They all say that.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: She spends a lot of time alone. I thought it might be nice if she had something to keep her company.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yeah. Sure. I bet. How do I know you're not the kind of guy who punches out parakeets? Or takes some poor defenseless animal, throws it in a sack and runs over it with your car five or six times.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I would never hurt an animal.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Boy, I would. They're driving me CRAZY!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Shuddup!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Okay... tell me more about this broad you're married to. I like to match people with the pets they deserve.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Uh-uh.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You do all my paperwork?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Get out of here.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: And a damn good job, too. One of 'em even did it in Spanish.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Hey Ned! Catch this! Friend of yours.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Jesus... you hear that?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: He's just working through his anger, trying to find a constructive outlet.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Are you kiddin'! He'll do it! The guy's a friggin' looney!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Trust me, I spent a lot of time with him when I was preparing his case. He's really a very sweet, sensitive human being.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: I'd like to mash his head like a ripe melon...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: He gets a little melon-dramatic.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: ...then cut off all his fingers and rip out his liver with my teeth!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: See. Loves to exaggerate.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Christ, Ned... you're in deep shit.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Lieutenant Ravine.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I want to see you, Ned.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: It's done! OVER!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Wrong number.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How come we gotta meet here?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: We have to be careful now. We can't risk being seen together at the house or someone might connect us to the murder later on.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Here... put this on.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Speak Yiddish.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Red Yiddish.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Ich hobe getracht, efsher iz der nisht geshtoigen un nisht gefloygen.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Zein nisht azoy meshige! Der plan iz kosher vi yosher.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yo! Ober mir darfen imvarfen in tsug. Un schissen un schtippen in vasser arein. Oy a broch! Mir zenen git bakackt.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Vus iz mit idr? Die host a vaichen schmoke?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Ven hob ich gehat a vaichen schmoke?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Lest'n Yomkippur.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Nu shoin, ein mul. Es paseert tsie yeyden man.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oy! Mir vellen zein oif groise tsures. Me'vet unz chap'n.

Speaker: older gentleman
Dialogue: There's very little risk involved. Statistics reveal that less than thirty-two percent of all murderers are ever apprehended.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: You speak Yiddish?

Speaker: older gentleman
Dialogue: No. But I can read sub-titles.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh gee, you shouldn't have...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I didn't. It's for my wife.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: She called. Wondered why you never came home last night. I told her you were working with a client, undercover.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Were you?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: There's lipstick on your collar.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No there isn't.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: No... there isn't. But you answered my question. She's a real looker, huh?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Lola Cain.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I hadn't noticed.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Yeah, I noticed how you hadn't noticed.  That's alright. She noticed enough for both of us.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I worry about you, Ned. I worry a lot.  Max Shady's been faxing death threats to you all morning.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...drive razor-sharp spikes under your...

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Did you get to the one...?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...cut it off... shove it in a blender.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Yeah... that one.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: He's just getting it out of his system. Once they say it... they never do it. You know... like the President.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Wait. It might be him.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Where did you get that?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: From my purse.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What are you doing with it?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Handing it to you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Jeez, Laura, what do you use a gun for?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: You shoot it. A bullet comes out. Gosh, Ned, after all your years as a cop, I'd think you'd know these things.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Laura... put the gun away.

Speaker: delivery man
Dialogue: Hey... aren't you that lawyer guy? Man, you are dead meat!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Is this another sick joke from Max Shady?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What is it...?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Lola Cain.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I'll put these in water for you.

Speaker: lola's voice
Dialogue: Ned, darling... I know this seems like a strange way to talk with you... but since you won't take my calls, I have no other choice.  Watch it! That red car's turning left!

Speaker: lola's voice
Dialogue: I love you, Ned. We're meant to be together... forever.  The light's changing! Floor it! Go! Go! Go!

Speaker: lola's voice
Dialogue: Nice move!  Nothing can keep us apart, Ned. Not even your wife. I'd hate to have to tell her about us, but if necessary... I will.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: What happened to you last night?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Why? What have you heard?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: You could have called. But then, I suppose you were tied up.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Only part of the time.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I never know when you're coming home, Ned. How can I ever make any plans?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I promise I'll spend more time with you. I know it's been rough, being alone so much. But I'll make it up to you. Maybe we should try again, you know... to have a baby.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: So what's in the box?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Oh... I brought you a present!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: It's... sorta like a cat.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Not enough like a cat.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: It's a little skunk. I got it at Birds-and-Skunks-R-Us.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: So... what're you going to name him?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: How about... Ned?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. Got a nice ring to it. I've always liked the name Ned.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: No kidding.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: So whatdya think? You love Ned Junior as much as you love me?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: At least.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Hello?... Hello?... Hello?  Frank? Is that you?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I told you not to call. Frank? FRANK!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Who's Frank?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Frank? The only Frank I know is an auto mechanic... but I sure as hell wouldn't recommend the guy. He's really slow.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I had to see you, Ned. I need to feel your arms around me! I wanna suck your toes til the nails pop off!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I told you, what happened was a big mistake. A one night stand. It's over. I have a wife...

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: It doesn't matter. She'll know all about us soon anyway. I want YOU! In my bed... in my arms... in MEEEEEEE!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I got us tickets to see Iron Butterfly!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I hate opera!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Why are you running from me? Didn't it mean ANYTHING to you?... buffing my buns with carnuba wax?  Come on, Neddy-poo. Doesn't Mr. Pokey want to go exploring?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: He's busy right now.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Look, I told you... Mr. Pokey made a big mistake! One lousy mistake in his whole stinkin' life! So why don't you give him a BREAK! Besides... he belongs to my wife!

Speaker: judge arugula
Dialogue: I'd like to congratulate Mr. Pokey for setting yet another unusual legal precedent. This is the first time I've ever tried a case in which the JURY was found to be insane.

Speaker: bailiff
Dialogue: What're you? A thirty-eight long?

Speaker: judge arugula
Dialogue: The jury will be remanded to the Center For Unclear Thinking in Simi Valley. Court's adjourned.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Your BIRTHDAY! Today? Why didn't you tell me?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: It's not important. I just had one last year.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Well, I'm taking you out to celebrate!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh no no! It's no big thing. I'll have another one sometime.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I insist. And I want to get you a nice present.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: You're so sweet. You don't have to. You gave me a present last year. Those lovely Ginzu knives.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah... aren't they great! They last forever. And you can cut right through a shoe with 'em!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: It's nice to be off the streets... away from all the pain and misery out there.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh, uh... I just wanted to remind you about...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...the Legal Symposium...

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: ...in Santa Barbara...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...tomorrow...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. I'm driving up in the morning.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: What is it, Ned? You can tell me.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'm a man, Laura. And all men feel passion at one time or another. Even me.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What would you think of a married man who gave in to those wild, sensual, raging desires?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh... wow... golly...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What if, for just one crazy moment, he couldn't resist...? He got knocked for a loop and lost control?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Gosh... that might be okay.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What if a tidal wave of lust crashed over him and he was sucked into a vortex of wild, thrashing urges?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Well... it's not your problem. I'll work it out.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Like some ice for your drink?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Does your wife know you're... "working" late? I certainly hope so, Mr. Ravine.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Hurry up, darling. You'll be late!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's all taken care of. When do I knock on the door?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Wait until I signal you. When I raise the blinds... you knock.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Not now!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh, later... right... okay.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Drive carefully, sweetheart. Say bye- bye to Little Ned. He loves his daddy... don't you Stink Pot?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: See you tonight, Junior.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: This neighborhood is getting worse all the time! Damn kids stole my engine!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Why don't you catch the train to Santa Barbara? It leaves in twenty minutes.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'll just fly up.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I mean... you can't. Armed terrorists seized the airport this morning. A plane crashed into the tower... and all the runways are on fire!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. So?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: And it's fogged in.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Dammit.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: For my peace of mind... take the train.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I can't do it. You know how I feel about riding trains.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Darling... it's only a short trip.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah... right. A short trip.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: A short trip to hell in a metal tomb!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Just because both your parents died in a train wreck...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And my brother, Jeff...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: And your brother, Morty...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: My two sisters...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Right...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: My best friend, Al... my dog, Woof... Grandma Rose... and Uncle Lionel. All killed by trains!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Coincidence, Ned. Beside... that's the past. They're gone.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. I guess I can't bring them back by not riding on a train.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But I just can't get over this stupid nagging fear that...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Fear! What about our baby, Ned? I don't want to raise a child in a home filled with fear!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: But if you can conquer your fear... maybe I can conquer my fear of having a baby with a father who's fearful.  Ned... don't let a train kill our child before it's even conceived!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I guess you're right.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: You're sure now...?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But we'll never make it to the station. By the time a cab gets here...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I was in the neighborhood. Thought I'd stop by and pick up my tools.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Frank will drive you. Won't you Frank?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Sure, I'll take you to the train station.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Twelve minutes. We'll never make it.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: We're not going to make it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We'll make it!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Okay... now what're you going to do if you feel queasy going through the tunnel?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'll stand in the vestibule between the cars.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: That's right. When you get queasy... go stand in the vestibule between the cars.

Speaker: woman passenger
Dialogue: OH! My dear gracious!

Speaker: irritable man
Dialogue: SIR! Would you PLEASE extinguish that foul smelling cigar?

Speaker: max
Dialogue: You want me to put out my CIGAR? YOU want me to put out my cigar? You want ME to put out my CIGAR?

Speaker: irritable man
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: It's already getting to him. He'll be out of that seat and into the vestibule within ten minutes... I guarantee it.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: You talkin' to me? You talkin' to ME? You... talkin'... to... ME?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Ticket?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Sorry pal... automatic weapons are only allowed in the club car after nine p.m.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: I'll check it with baggage. You can claim it at the depot in Santa Barbara.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Hi! I'm Jeff and I'm eight years old. Didja know if ya put a penny on the track it'll make the train crash? No kiddin'! You ever been in a wreck? My uncle has. Lotsa times. It's really neat. Everybody gets creamed! All bloody guts... heads ripped off and stuff... Hey... wanna hear my song "Great Green Gobs of Greasy Grimy Gopher Guts"?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: You want to earn a couple bucks, kid?

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Hi! I'm Jeff and I'm eight years old. Didja know if ya put a penny on the track it'll make the train crash?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: He's losing it. You better get up to the next car. Remember, give me the high sign as soon as you see the river. It'll be two minutes and nine seconds past the tunnel. I'll take care of the rest. Anything goes wrong... just make sure you back me up.  And don't let him see you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: This... is not a toy!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Yes it is.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: Here... let me help you with that.

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: What a nice young man. You are so polite.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: I try to be.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Great green gobs of greasy, grimy gopher guts... mutilated monkey meat... chopped up dirty birdie's feet... one pint jar of all-purpose porpoise pus... cooked in a Mulligan stew.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: French fried eyeballs and ugly scabs you wanna pick... stuff to make your mother sick... dog poop on a stick... puke and snot all mixed together in a pot...

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Oh boy! Here comes the tunnel!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Way to go, Ned. Right on time.

Speaker: max
Dialogue: You shootin' at me?

Speaker: max
Dialogue: Yeah... you're definitely shootin' at me.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: In this crazy world, there's not a whole lot a guy can count on. But when the chips are down, I can always count on you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You risked your life to save mine. A guy can't ask any more from a woman than that.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But I saw you shoot him, Lana. In cold blood. I gotta arrest you for murder.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Ned... you wouldn't...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Sorry. I'm a cop. I have a job to do.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: But... you said it yourself. I saved your life.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Don't worry, baby. I know a good lawyer.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That's a question for the arresting officer.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You'll have to ask her attorney.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Only her husband can answer that.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: A lovely powder blue dress with a cinch waist, full bodice and a delicately pleated skirt.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No comment.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I said... NO COMMENT!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Jeez... they're really throwing some tough questions out there today.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: They're just doing their job.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah... well I call it a "high-tech lynching of an uppity white housewife."

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: Only cell available. They had that serial killer locked up here... you know, the one who talks his victims to death then eats them... Hannibal the Lecturer. But they let him out for a three week tour to publicize his new book.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: "To Serve Man."

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: It's a cookbook.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: And look, look... he autographed it.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Very nice.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: They're waiting for ya. They didn't want to start without her attorney being present.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: PFFFTT! Damn moths! This place could use a good exterminator.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Can't you get me out of this cage, Ned? I'm goin' buggy in here.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Judge said no bail. Don't worry. Just tell the truth, you'll be fine.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Who's gonna handle the interrogation?

Speaker: investigator 1
Dialogue: It's your collar... your bust... your call... your show... your play... your move... your wife...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Okay, okay!... I'll handle it.

Speaker: investigator 2
Dialogue: Sorry Mrs. Ravine... there's no makeup allowed in this building.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: What're you gonna do... arrest me for primping?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Don't give us a tough time. Just spill it! What were you doing on that train?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: As your attorney, I must advise you... you don't have to answer that question.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Alright, quit playing games with us!  Who put ya up to it? Where'd you get the gun? What's your link with the CIA?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Whoa whoa whoa whoa! That's it! I will not tolerate this unwarranted badgering of my client. She'll have her day in court, gentlemen.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I want to thank you, Mrs. Ravine, for being so cooperative with these gentlemen.  Did you get all that down, Laura. Every word she said?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Yep. Both of 'em.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: NO!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: NOOOOO!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: NOOOOOOOooooooo!!!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: YES! Cappelini pomodoro!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Pasta with tomato sauce. Whatsa matta? You don't like Italian?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Where's Ned Junior? WHERE IS HE?!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I thought he might like to get out, so I took him to the amusement park.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You can't just break into my house, cook my food... borrow my skunk!  Leave me alone. Stay out of my face! Out of my neighborhood! Out of my LIFE!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: You haven't seen the last of me, Ned.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I told you.

Speaker: cheerleaders
Dialogue: Lana, Lana, she's the one Shot a bad guy with a gun Blew that sucker off a train Some guys are a friggin' pain YaaaaaAAAAAAAAY LANA!

Speaker: commentator
Dialogue: Once again, Americans are making a mockery of their courts, turning a murder trial into a media circus! How can justice ever prevail when it is ridiculed and reviled in such a heinously revolting manner? This is Clement Von Franckenstein returning you to our BBC studios in London for the latest photographs of Lady Di naked in the bath.

Speaker: sportscaster
Dialogue: What a great day for a trial! We have lots of incandescent lighting, seventy-two degrees inside... and no wind!

Speaker: bailiff
Dialogue: Oy vay! Oy vay! Superior Court of Los Angeles is now in session. And here he is... direct from a triumphant one-week engagement in Las Vegas Circuit Court... the honorable... the venerable... the totally irrepressible... Judge Harlan Skan- kyyyyyyy!

Speaker: sportscaster
Dialogue: Wow... has this defense team been HOT! Thirty-seven straight victories this year! Let's go down for the coin toss.

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: ...the prosecution will prove that this repulsive and degenerate woman coldly murdered a decent, law-abiding citizen...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Objection! Move to strike. Hearsay, irrelevant, stupid, idiotic, caca- doody poo-poo...

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Sustained.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And can you tell us what this is?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Yes. It's a death threat that Max Shady FAXED to you on the day he was released from prison.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: A FAX in which he threatened to puree certain parts of my anatomy in a blender! I'd like to submit this into evidence.

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: Objection! Who cares about the FAX in this case?

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: I'll allow it.

Speaker: cheerleaders
Dialogue: U-G-L-Y! You ain't got no alibi! You're ugly! Yeah, you're ugly! M-A- M-A! How you think you got that way? Your Mama! Yeah, your Mama!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And is this the blender you found in the lavatory of the train?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Yes... it is.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'd like this marked as evidence.

Speaker: sportscaster
Dialogue: Awwwww... a bad call by Ravine. Let's check out the re-play.

Speaker: sportscaster
Dialogue: Look at THAT! The Bailiff is wide open! But instead of handing it off, Ravine goes for the long bomb. Ohhhh! The pass is wide! A real wobbler! There's no way! He scrambles, but he just can't get his hands on it... And RIGHT THERE!...  ...WHAM! That blender is gone!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Ned... did you ever consider that maybe you don't know women as well as you think you do?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'm really worried about this guy. He could blow our whole case right out of the water.

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: Great green gobs of greasy grimy gopher guts... mutilated monkey meat... itsy-bitsy birdie feet... Great green gobs of greasy grimy gopher guts... and me without a spoon!

Speaker: jeff
Dialogue: That lady paid me two bucks to sing it to him...!

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Recess! Ten minutes!

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: Gotcha, dork face! Gotcha, gotcha!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: No you didn't!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No way! Uh-uh! Missed by a mile!

Speaker: bailiff
Dialogue: Recess is over! Let's go... move it, move it, move it!

Speaker: sportscaster
Dialogue: There they go... the UCLA Marching Band! And now... Holy Toledo!... it looks like the victim's mother... Helen Shady... is gonna take the stand! This will be the first defensive play of the afternoon.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Mrs. Shady... would you tell us about your son, Max. Was he a... a good boy?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But he got into trouble once in awhile... like all kids do?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And what, uh... what are these...?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: This is cute.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And is this Max... with all the tools... fixing his bike?

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Mrs. Shady! Do not POINT your finger in my courtroom. It's discourteous, impolite and disrespectful.

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Sit down!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Did you encounter the victim... Max Shady... on board the train?

Speaker: irritable man
Dialogue: Yeah. And I told him... "this is the NO SMOKING car! Would you please put out your damn cigar!"

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And is that the cigar in your ear?

Speaker: irritable man
Dialogue: I believe it is.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'd like the cigar and the head of this witness entered into evidence.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: The defense calls... Lana Ravine!

Speaker: bailiff
Dialogue: Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth so help you God?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Do I have to answer that, Harlan?

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: No, no dear. I'll vouch for her.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Now, Mrs. Ravine... may I call you Lana?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: No. Call me Angel Tits.

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: I object!

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Sustained. Counselor... you will address Angel Tits as Mrs. Ravine.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Mrs. Ravine... would you please tell the court... what were you doing on that train?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I saw Max Shady at the station... saw him get on board. I knew he'd made threats to kill you and mutilate your reproductive organs...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: ...so I got on the train too... so I could warn you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Do you want to have children?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Someday. With the right man.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But you couldn't have children if my...  ...and, uh...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: It would be difficult.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: So you followed him, knowing you had to protect me... your husband... your best friend... the man you love... the future father of your children.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Something like that.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: And when you saw that maniac standing in the vestibule, waiting to pulverize my pee-pee... you pulled the gun and fired and fired and FIRED!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: And fired and fired and fired and fired and fired and fired and fired...

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: ...and fired and fired and fired.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: The defense rests, your Honor.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: How can you convict a courageous woman who risked everything to save the life of her beloved husband? A woman who acted boldly to stop a demented maniac from doing THIS!...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...pulverizing the private parts of the man she loves!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Lana Ravine is a loving wife and the potential mother of my potential child. I challenge YOU to strike a blow for motherhood and the American justice system! Put the "con" back in the Constitution. Put the "ju" back in jurisprudence. Put the "can" back in American. And put the "dom" back in freedom. Find this woman INNOCENT!... so we can all go to bed happy tonight!

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: The jury's back!

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: So... has the jury reached a verdict?

Speaker: jury foreman
Dialogue: Yes we have, your Honor.

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: How do you find the defendant... on the count of manslaughter?

Speaker: jury foreman
Dialogue: Not guilty.

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: On the count of murder in the first degree?

Speaker: jury foreman
Dialogue: Not guilty.

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: On the Count of Monte Cristo?

Speaker: jury foreman
Dialogue: Not guilty.

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Good. Then on the count of three, let's all get the hell out of here! One... two...

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Wait... for... it...

Speaker: judge skanky
Dialogue: Two and a half... THREE!

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Well, counselor, looks like you won another case. Lucky for me.

Speaker: irritable woman
Dialogue: I told you, Bernard... smoking cigars is bad for your hearing!

Speaker: court clerk
Dialogue: Mrs. Ravine! What can I do for ya?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: How much for my gun?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I don't believe it! She just bought her gun back! The gun she used to kill a man!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah... the same gun that saved my life. I'm sure it has sentimental value.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: So... you did it. Ya beat the rap.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: No thanks to you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hey... I knew he'd spring ya.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: You didn't lift a finger, Frank. You let me take all the heat.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Heeeee-eeey... what could I do?

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: You were gonna let me rot in the slammer... never say a thing.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Look... you're out... free. Now we're together. That's what counts. We can try again! Forget triple indemnity. We'll whack him and split three mil.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I'm not splitting anything, Frank.  And you know too much.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Come on, Lana. You're not gonna shoot me.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: You're right.  Maybe I'll just screw you to death.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Now you're talkin' baby.

Speaker: forensic man
Dialogue: Watch your step, guys. There's a lot of blood.

Speaker: investigator
Dialogue: Looks like a suicide. We found a note.

Speaker: investigator
Dialogue: It was stuck up his nose.

Speaker: arch
Dialogue: "I can't take it anymore. I'm a mediocre mechanic... and a lousy lover."

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: He's sure got that right.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: The "mechanic" part, I mean.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I don't know why, Arch, but I just can't shake this crazy hunch it wasn't suicide.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: Oh... uh, Ned... This is Lola, um...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Um? She told you her name was Um? And what other lies did she tell you? I've never seen this woman in my life! Never followed her home! Never had sex with her in the refrigerator! It's all a sick fantasy... and I deny everything!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: When will women like you learn, you can't tear apart a perfectly good marriage with your vicious lies... Miss UMMMM!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Actually... it's Smith. Lola Smith. I sell vacuum cleaners, Mr. Ravine. The big powerful kind that suck up everything in sight. I was just telling your wife, if she wants to get rid of all her dirt, she has to be willing to pay the price.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Let me know what you decide, Mrs. Ravine. I'm sure we can work out a convenient "payment" plan. A pleasure meeting you... Ned.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I... hate... SALESMEN!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I know it's been a tough ordeal... with the trial and everything. Tell you what... let's take a trip.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: A trip?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. Just the two of us.

Speaker: lana
Dialogue: I like that. Just you and me... all alone. I'll start packing.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Great. Listen... I got something to take care of. I'll be back in awhile.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I just want to talk.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Why didn't you say so?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Would you like a drink?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: No thanks. I'm driving.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Then let's get to the point!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: So what's your problem, tough guy?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Stay away from my life, my wife, my home and my pets! I'm taking Lana on a vacation and when I come back, I don't ever want to see your face again!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: A VACATION! She doesn't deserve a VACATION! She's a brat! A bad girl! She always was and always will be!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What are you talking about? You don't know anything about Lana?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I know EVERYTHING!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: How do you know her? Who is she to you? TELL ME!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Who is she!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: She's your wife!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Who is she!?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: She's my sister!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Liar! Who is she?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: She's your wife!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: WHO IS SHE!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: She's my sister!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: She's your wife... AND my sister!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: She was spoiled rotten! She stole everything I ever had. Everything! Including him.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Him? Who, him?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Dwayne. The boy's gym teacher. He was older. So mature... so strong. He smelled like dirty sweat socks and old basketballs. And he was all mine. For awhile.  But Lana wasn't satisfied with her own things. She had to have mine too. She took it all... my makeup, my sweaters, my shoes, my underwear...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You wore the same clothes?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: We were identical twins.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: What're you talking about? You two don't look anything alike.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Not anymore. One day I caught her stealing my lavender eye shadow and she smashed my face in with a shovel. I had fifty-three operations. When the doctors were finished with me... I looked like THIS! I'm ugly. UGLY!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You're beautiful.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Don't lie to me.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: They did a terrific job!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I look in the mirror. I can SEE!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: But... you're gorgeous!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Tell that to Dwayne. When he saw my face, he left me for HER... because she looked more like me than I did! First she stole my looks... then she stole the only man who ever loved me!

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: But I found a way to get even. The best revenge possible. Destroy her marriage!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That's why you did all this? Seduced me... harrassed me... the tape... the flowers... the phone calls...

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: You been hangin' out with Dick Tracy, haven't ya?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: It won't work. Lana loves me.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: It doesn't matter. I'm blackmailing her for everything she's worth. She murdered that greasy auto mechanic. I saw her do it.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Lana killed Frank Kelbo?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Kelbo! His name was Kelbo?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah. Why? Did he burn you on car repairs too?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Dwayne's name was Kelbo. He had a son. Frankie Kelbo.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Lana?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Ned! I'm glad you're here. I have so much to tell you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Come on in. I'll make some tea. Grab a chair.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Thanks... I brought my own.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: So... what have you got?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: A lottery ticket and a laundry receipt.  I found them in the pocket of that suit you wore the night you were working under cover with a client.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: You remember that night, don't ya Ned? Then it hit me. Lottery starts with L-O. Laundry starts with L-A. L- O... L-A. Lola.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Don't sweat it. It's the way a woman's mind works.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: How about Ovaltine?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Fine. Then I remembered you told me some guy named Frank had been working on your wife's car for two months. You with me so far?

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I'm way ahead of you.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Well back it up. You probably took a wrong turn. Remember your insurance policy... the one we couldn't find? I started thinking, who else had access to it beside you and me? The answer came up... Lana. And since she's a woman, it's probably hidden right here.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: So that's where she hid the Oreos.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Ned, Lana wasn't trying to save your life when she shot Max Shady. She and Frank were plotting to kill you and collect on your insurance policy. But she shot the wrong guy.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That's the craziest thing I ever heard.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: That's when I realized there was a connection between Lola and Lana...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah... they're sisters. Twin sisters.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Well, hang on to your jock strap, Ned. There's more.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Not only is Frank's father Dwayne Kelbo, notoriously amorous gym teacher and Lola Cain's former lover... Frank's mother is Helen Shady. Max and Frank are half-brothers who never met.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Your lovely wife, Lana, murdered both of Helen Shady's sons.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: This is so unbelievable.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: And you haven't even heard my story.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: He turned into a monster. And that's when I left him. I just couldn't...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: That damn faucet keeps turning on all by itself. I'll go check it.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Okay. I'll make the Ovaltine.

Speaker: guest musician
Dialogue: I'm sittin' in for Dizzy. He had a gig tonight.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Women are an open book. You can always tell the rotten apples from the peaches. I'd stake my career on it... stake my career on it... stake my career on it...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...If anyone ever proves me wrong, I'll throw away my badge.

Speaker: laura's husband
Dialogue: Forget something, sweetheart?

Speaker: laura's husband
Dialogue: You forgot to flush, darling.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: What're you gonna do, Ned? Blow me away?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I never forget anything... honey.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Those are MY panties!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh Ned!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: You were right... there's a million things I don't know about women. Maybe you can teach me a few hundred.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Hell... I had too many careers anyway.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Oh Ned, I love you. I always loved you!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Got 'em!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: WHAT?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: I said... I GOT 'EM!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: HUH?!!!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: THEY'RE DEAD! GONE! KA-PUT!

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: SURE I'LL MARRY YOU! NEXT TUESDAY WOULD BE PERFECT!

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Okay. But I want to have kids.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: ...understand women... give birth... and program a VCR. And giving birth is the easy one.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Ned...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah, Laura?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: Knock off the chatter, will ya?

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: We won't need you anymore.

Speaker: laura
Dialogue: We can make our own music.
